item.title: R vs Python: What's the difference?
item.description: Despite clear differences in syntax and command execution, both R and Python 3 have the ability to excel in performing identical tasks. I’m choosing to demonstrate this using the built-in iris dataset, which contains information on the dimensions of four different species of iris flowers. I’ll narrow down the observations to those where the flower’s sepal length is longer than the median value and then make a scatterplot demonstrating the relationship between sepal width and petal width for this subset.

item.title: Projects
item.description: Projects Here are some projects I have recently completed: Exploratory Data Analysis with Tidyverse Tools Modeling, Testing, and Classification

item.title: Project 1 - Analysis of Global GDP and Population Data
item.description: Carson Manley cwm2477 Introduction The three datasets selected for this project were pulled from World Bank Open Data, a source for financial and demographic records spanning the entire globe. I chose to examine worldwide data for population, percent GDP growth and per-capita GDP. Observations range from 1961-2018, although data was not collected until relatively recently for some countries. If population has some bearing on the size of a country’s economy, there may be an inverse relationship between population and percent GDP growth.

item.title: Project 2
item.description: Carson Manley cwm2477 class_diag<-function(probs,truth){ if(is.numeric(truth)==FALSE & is.logical(truth)==FALSE) truth<-as.numeric(truth)-1 tab<-table(factor(probs>.5,levels=c("FALSE","TRUE")),truth) prediction<-ifelse(probs>.5,1,0) acc=mean(truth==prediction) sens=mean(prediction[truth==1]==1) spec=mean(prediction[truth==0]==0) ppv=mean(truth[prediction==1]==1) #CALCULATE EXACT AUC ord<-order(probs, decreasing=TRUE) probs <- probs[ord]; truth <- truth[ord] TPR=cumsum(truth)/max(1,sum(truth)) FPR=cumsum(!truth)/max(1,sum(!truth)) dup<-c(probs[-1]>=probs[-length(probs)], FALSE) TPR<-c(0,TPR[!dup],1); FPR<-c(0,FPR[!dup],1) n <- length(TPR) auc<- sum( ((TPR[-1]+TPR[-n])/2) * (FPR[-1]-FPR[-n]) ) data.frame(acc,sens,spec,ppv,auc) } library(tidyverse) ## ── Attaching packages ─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse 1.3.0 ── ## ✓ ggplot2 3.2.1 ✓ purrr 0.3.3 ## ✓ tibble 2.1.3 ✓ dplyr 0.8.3 ## ✓ tidyr 1.
